inlineContent.text: This API has been soft-deprecated in favor of 'ReducerProtocol'. Read the migration guide for more information: https://pointfreeco.github.io/swift-composable-architecture/main/documentation/composablearchitecture/reducerprotocol

inlineContent.text: A reducer describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state, given
an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if any.
Reducers have 3 generics:
: A type that holds the current state of the application.
: A type that holds all possible actions that cause the state of the application to
change.
: A type that holds all dependencies needed in order to produce
s, such as API clients, analytics clients, random number generators, etc.
The thread on which effects output is important. An effect’s output is immediately
sent back into the store, and
is not thread safe. This means all effects must
receive values on the same thread,
and
if the
is being used to drive UI then all
output must be on the main thread. You can use the
method
for make
the effect output its values on the thread of your choice.
This is only an issue if using the Combine interface of
as mentioned
above. If you are only using Swift’s concurrency tools and the
and
functions on
, then the threading is automatically handled for
you.

The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
Evolves the current state of the reducer to the next state.
